qas.question: When did Russian musika show up?
khorovïye kontsertï were typically done similar to what pieces?
What bible passage gave rise to certain a cappella attitudes?
Who composed a popular Venetian-styled piece in 1675?
What is based on a brad interpritation of the Psalms?
What started appearing in Russia in the 1700's?
What was a copy of Venetian a cappella?
What was written by NIkolai Diletsky in the 16th century?
How are liturgies sung in Russian musika?
What motivates the way instrumental music is composed in the church?
When did the Byzantine Rite of the Eastern Orothdox Church appear?
What type of music made a cappella versions of instrumental accompaniment?
What Bishop composed Grammatika musikiyskaya in 1675?

context: In the Byzantine Rite of the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Eastern Catholic Churches, the music performed in the liturgies is <b8_0>exclusively sung without instrumental accompaniment<b8_0/>. Bishop Kallistos Ware says, "The service is sung, even though there may be no choir... In the Orthodox Church today, as in the early Church, singing is unaccompanied and instrumental music is not found." This <b4_0>a cappella behavior<b4_0/> arises from <b9_0>strict interpretation of <a2_0>Psalms 150<b9_0/><a2_0/>, which states, Let every thing that hath breath praise the Lord. Praise ye the Lord. In keeping with this philosophy, early Russian <b5_0>musika<b5_0/> which started appearing in <b10_0>the late 17th century<b10_0/>, in what was known as <a0_0><b6_0><b11_0>khorovïye kontsertï<b6_0/><a0_0/> (choral concertos)<b11_0/> made a cappella adaptations of <a1_0>Venetian-styled<a1_0/> pieces, such as the treatise, <b7_0>Grammatika musikiyskaya<b7_0/> (1675), by <a3_0><b12_0>Nikolai Diletsky<b12_0/><a3_0/>. Divine Liturgies and Western Rite masses composed by famous composers such as Peter Tchaikovsky, Sergei Rachmaninoff, Alexander Arkhangelsky, and Mykola Leontovych are fine examples of this.
